presentation: Bursting, aching pain developing with exercise
Continues or worsens with continued walking
Leg becomes swollen and cyanotic with exercise
Requires elevation (not just rest) for relief
Often associated with limb edema at rest
diagnosis: Clinical history distinguishing from arterial claudication
CT or MR venography for anatomic detail
Ambulatory venous pressure measurement (invasive gold standard)
treatment: Anticoagulation if acute or recurrent thrombosis
Compression therapy (supportive but limited efficacy for obstruction)
Surgical bypass for extensive disease (rare, last resort)

definition.@value: Exercise-induced lower extremity pain caused by severe venous outflow obstruction, where arterial inflow during activity exceeds the capacity of the obstructed venous system, causing venous engorgement, compartment hypertension, and bursting leg pain relieved by elevation.

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Distinguish venous claudication from arterial claudication
Identify clinical features suggesting iliofemoral obstruction
Apply appropriate diagnostic testing for venous claudication
Describe treatment options for iliofemoral obstruction
clinical_pearls: Venous claudication: bursting pain, cyanosis, needs elevation vs. arterial: cramping, pallor, rest works
History of extensive DVT is a key clue
Normal ABI does not exclude claudication - it may be venous!
IVUS is critical for assessing iliofemoral stenosis - more accurate than venography
Iliac stenting has excellent outcomes for venous claudication
